MC	<p>bc05_23c4</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene J</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">81</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008066;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">4,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes A and R is 4 cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and J is 23 cM</li><li>The distance between genes R and J is 20 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>ARJ</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes A and J.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.1250 = 12%	Incorrect	C. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.3750 = 38%	Correct	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.6250 = 62%	Incorrect	F. <sup>7</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.8750 = 88%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>73d7_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; background-color: #f3e6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">9</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">prickly</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6fff3; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">p</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">13</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008066;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f3e6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">806</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008066;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">165</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,200</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes P and A is 10 cM</li><li>The distance between genes P and Y is 24 cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and Y is 16 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>PAY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes P and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.1250 = 12%	Incorrect	C. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.3750 = 38%	Correct	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.6250 = 62%	Incorrect	F. <sup>7</sup>/<sub>8</sub> = 0.8750 = 88%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>1756_38cc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene D</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene P</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene Y</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">7,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes D and P is 25 cM</li><li>The distance between genes D and Y is 28 cM</li><li>The distance between genes P and Y is 5 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>DPY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes D and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.2000 = 20%	Correct	C. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.4000 = 40%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.6000 = 60%	Incorrect	F. <sup>4</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.8000 = 80%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>6f2d_38cc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene F</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">x</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,522</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #99004d;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">328</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">7,700</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes F and D is 25 cM</li><li>The distance between genes F and X is 33 cM</li><li>The distance between genes D and X is 10 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>FDX</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes F and X.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.2000 = 20%	Incorrect	C. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.4000 = 40%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.6000 = 60%	Correct	F. <sup>4</sup>/<sub>5</sub> = 0.8000 = 80%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>2809_2477</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and X is 38 cM</li><li>The distance between genes J and X is 30 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>AJX</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes A and X.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.0909 = MC	<p>e856_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene P</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>e31d_10af</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene E</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene H</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> </ul></p><table color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #465927;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #800055;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes E and A is 14 cM</li><li>The distance between genes E and H is 22 cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and H is 10 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>EAH</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes E and H.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.1429 = 14%	Incorrect	C. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.2857 = 29%	Correct	D. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.4286 = 43%	Incorrect	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. <sup>4</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.5714 = 57%	Incorrect	G. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.7143 = 71%	Incorrect	H. <sup>6</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.8571 = 86%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>f33e_f4f2</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene H</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px <strong>DXH</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the MC	<p>fdaa_596f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene F</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene M</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, mushy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ecff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">m</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">477</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, mushy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ecff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">m</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">mushy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ecff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">m</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #99004d;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">81</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">3</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #99004d;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">489</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">1,200</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes F and Y is 5 cM</li><li>The distance between genes F and M is 19 cM</li><li>The distance between genes Y and M is 15 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>FYM</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes F and M.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>d2da_9c3b</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene F</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene H</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene J</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: cM</li><li>The distance between genes F and J is 37 cM</li><li>The distance between genes H and J is 15 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>FHJ</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes F and J.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>9</sub> = 0.1111 = 11%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>9</sub> = 0.5556 = 56%	Incorrect	F. MC	<p>17b1_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene N</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene P</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #800055;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">270</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6f9; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">118</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #800055;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">12</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">4,600</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes P and N is 5 cM</li><li>The distance between genes P and Y is 16 cM</li><li>The distance between genes N and Y is 12 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>PNY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes P and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.1667 = 17%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	F. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.8333 = 83%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>2af5_596f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">bumpy, rusty, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #fff9e5; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">b</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6fff3; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">3,127</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008066;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">46</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">8,200</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes B and Y is 15 cM</li><li>The distance between genes B and R is 23 cM</li><li>The distance between genes Y and R is 10 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>BYR</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes B and R.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>ee9f_40f0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene B</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene D</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene N</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> </ul></p><table cM</li><li>The distance between genes B and D is 39 cM</li><li>The distance between genes N and D is 30 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>BND</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes B and D.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.0833 = 8%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.2500 = 25%	Incorrect	D. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.4167 = 42%	Incorrect	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. <sup>7</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.5833 = 58%	Incorrect	G. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.7500 = 75%	Incorrect	H. <sup>11</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.9167 = 92%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>763d_596f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene H</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6f9; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">h</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #800055;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">1,126</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">3,700</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes B and F is 30 cM</li><li>The distance between genes B and H is 38 cM</li><li>The distance between genes F and H is 10 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>BFH</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes B and H.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Correct	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>f598_38cc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene M</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene J</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene P</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">d</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ecffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">j</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">prickly</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f3e6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">p</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,587</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">201</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">7,400</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes D and J is 25 cM</li><li>The distance between genes D and P is 29 cM</li><li>The distance between genes J and P is 6 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>DJP</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes D and P.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>8e0d_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene B</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene J</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse;
