background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">12</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">mushy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ecffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">m</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ecff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">12</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">mushy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ecffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">m</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">373</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ecff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">35</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">789</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,400</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes M and J is 30 cM</li><li>The distance between genes M and Y is 32 cM</li><li>The distance between genes J and Y is 4 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>MJY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes M and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.1667 = 17%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	F. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.8333 = 83%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>34b2_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene N</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene X</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">nerdy, xanthic, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>b1fc_9bcc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #002db3;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">13</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">4,200</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes R and A is 25 cM</li><li>The distance between genes R and Y is 32 cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and Y is 8 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>RAY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes R and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.2500 = 25%	Incorrect	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.7500 = 75%	Correct	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>906e_9bcc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene K</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">kidney, nerdy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">6,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes N and K is 20 cM</li><li>The distance between genes N and Y is 27 cM</li><li>The distance between genes K and Y is 10 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>NKY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes N and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.2500 = 25%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.7500 = 75%	Incorrect	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>ae54_9bcc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene B</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene E</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene P</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>f200_596f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene J</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene N</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #465927;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f3e6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">n</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">337</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b34100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #465927;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">12</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,500</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes C and J is 30 cM</li><li>The distance between genes C and N is 38 cM</li><li>The distance between genes J and N is 10 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>CJN</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes C and N.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	D. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Correct	E. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>aa99_40f0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene D</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene K</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and K is 39 cM</li><li>The distance between genes D and K is 30 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>ADK</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes A and K.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.0833 = 8%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.2500 = 25%	Incorrect	D. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.4167 = 42%	Incorrect	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>f2ae_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">390</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">xanthic, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6f9ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">x</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">393</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">xanthic</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6f9ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">x</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #99004d;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,153</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">y</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">299</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #99004d;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">38</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">5,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes A and X is 12 cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and Y is 24 cM</li><li>The distance between genes X and Y is 15 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>AXY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes A and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.1667 = 17%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	F. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.8333 = 83%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>be3e_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene M</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>4e00_40f0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene K</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">4,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes E and F is 6 cM</li><li>The distance between genes E and K is 25 cM</li><li>The distance between genes F and K is 20 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>EFK</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes E and K.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.0833 = 8%	Incorrect	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.2500 = 25%	Incorrect	D. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.4167 = 42%	Incorrect	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. <sup>7</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.5833 = 58%	Correct	G. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub> = 0.7500 = 75%	Incorrect	H. <sup>11</sup>/<sub>12</sub> = 0.9167 = 92%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>c3bf_9bcc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene P</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene T</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>5ea6_10af</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px MC	<p>ab5c_10af</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene J</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene P</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">59</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes J and P is 6 cM</li><li>The distance between genes J and W is 38 cM</li><li>The distance between genes P and W is 35 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>JPW</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes J and W.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.1429 = 14%	Incorrect	C. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.2857 = 29%	Correct	D. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.4286 = 43%	Incorrect	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. <sup>4</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.5714 = 57%	Incorrect	G. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.7143 = 71%	Incorrect	H. <sup>6</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.8571 = 86%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>eb5a_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene T</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">nerdy, tipsy, waxy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">7,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes T and N is 28 cM</li><li>The distance between genes T and W is 36 cM</li><li>The distance between genes N and W is 15 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>TNW</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes T and W.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.1667 = 17%	Correct	C. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.3333 = 33%	Incorrect	D. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	E. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>3</sub> = 0.6667 = 67%	Incorrect	F. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>6</sub> = 0.8333 = 83%	Incorrect	G. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>5621_84bd</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene R</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span background-color: #f3e6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">w</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008080;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #690f8a;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">2,180</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">6,700</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes R and A is 25 cM</li><li>The distance between genes R and W is 34 cM</li><li>The distance between genes A and W is 11 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>RAW</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes R and W.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.0909 = 9%	Incorrect	C. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.2727 = 27%	Incorrect	D. <sup>4</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.3636 = 36%	Incorrect	E. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.4545 = 45%	Incorrect	F. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	G. <sup>7</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.6364 = 64%	Correct	H. <sup>9</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.8182 = 82%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>8031_2477</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene B</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene F</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: <strong>BDF</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the MC	<p>d2db_10af</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene B</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene F</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">310</span></td></tr><tr><th colspan="4" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">TOTAL =</span></th><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">1,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes B and F is 35 cM</li><li>The distance between genes B and Y is 38 cM</li><li>The distance between genes F and Y is 5 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>BFY</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes B and Y.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.1429 = 14%	Incorrect	C. <sup>2</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.2857 = 29%	Incorrect	D. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.4286 = 43%	Correct	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. <sup>4</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.5714 = 57%	Incorrect	G. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.7143 = 71%	Incorrect	H. <sup>6</sup>/<sub>7</sub> = 0.8571 = 86%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>8083_baf0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene C</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene J</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>a936_10af</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene J</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene M</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> MC	<p>ff6c_e662</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene J</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #663300;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">5,800</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p><ul> <li>The distance between genes D and X is 15 cM</li><li>The distance between genes D and J is 39 cM</li><li>The distance between genes X and J is 33 cM</li><li>The correct gene order determined from these distances is <strong>DXJ</strong></li></ul></p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions for Calculating Interference</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Count the observed number of double crossovers from the data table.</li> <li>Step 2: Calculate the probability of independent crossovers between distant genes.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the two individual crossover probabilities (based on their distance) for both adjacent gene pairs.</li></ul> <li>Step 3: Determine the expected number of double crossovers.</li> <ul><li>Multiply the combined probability (from Step 2) by the total progeny count.</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Calculate the Coefficient of Coincidence (CoC).</li> <ul><li>Divide the observed number of double crossovers (from Step 1) by the expected number (from Step 3).</li></ul> <li>Step 5: Calculate Interference.</li> <ul><li>Interference is given by the formula: Interference = 1 - CoC.</li></ul></ul><p>In genetic studies, interference refers to the phenomenon where the occurrence of a crossover in one region of a chromosome reduces the likelihood of another crossover occurring nearby, thereby affecting the expected genetic ratios.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>Based on the traits expressed in the offspring, <strong>select the correct fraction that represents the interference level</strong> between genes D and J.</p>	A. no interference, 0%	Incorrect	B. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.0909 = 9%	Correct	C. <sup>3</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.2727 = 27%	Incorrect	D. <sup>5</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.4545 = 45%	Incorrect	E. <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> = 0.5000 = 50%	Incorrect	F. <sup>7</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.6364 = 64%	Incorrect	G. <sup>9</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.8182 = 82%	Incorrect	H. <sup>10</sup>/<sub>11</sub> = 0.9091 = 91%	Incorrect	I. complete interference, 100%	Incorrect
MC	<p>3ae5_9bcc</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>80a5_10af</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene H</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene N</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> </ul></p><table color: #000000;"><i>wildtype</i></span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008066;">+</span></td><td align="center"
